lines.text: [Major Towns has proposed a fool-hardy plan of attack]
The Major is in a hurry to get buried on a Montana mountain.
Yeah, he said he was gonna cross the Yellowstone and jump the Sioux.
Will he try a fool thing like that?
If he does, the ground is going to be full of soldiers.

The West was opened by courageous trail-blazing pioneers like Lewis & Clark and Luther "Yellowstone" Kelly - trapper, surveyor and Indian scout who was the first frontiersman to cross the mighty Yellowstone Valley.
You must be a tame Indian.
I wouldn't count on that.
Mr. Kelly, Major Towns extends his complements, sir. He'd like to see you in the Captain's quarters, sir.
He would?
Yes sir, on the double, sir.
You tell your major I've been a long time dry, Lieutenant. He'll have to wait.
Well, he says it's important, sir.
To him or me?
If I go and lead you up the Snake, like as not, you won't have anybody to bugle over ya.
In other words, you refuse.
In any words, I refuse.
That's the trouble with Indians. You'll never know what they'll do next. Neither do they.
When you were a boy, did you ever go out in the woods and catch something wild - a rabbit or bird - take it home with you to keep?
Yes, sir.
Well, what happened?
Well...
I'll tell you what happened. It either got sick, ran away or died. It's the same way with an Indian. You go trying to tame them, make them live white... it just won't work.
I wish I could take that grin off his face.
He's proud... counting coup on us.
Coup?

That stick he clubbed us with! A coup stick. Horseback Indians figure anybody can stand safe off and kill a man, but if you can get close enough to touch him and then ride away alive, that's something to tell your squaw about.
Planning on crossing the river, are you?
I told you I was going to drive the Sioux back to the Dakotas. That's what I intend to do.
I knew a man once... he intended to kill a bear with a stick. I buried him.
I'll tell you once more, Major. On this side you're in trouble, over there, you're dead!
No man can take my love. It must be given as the sun gives warmth in the gray of dawn.
